lexUnit.name: phrase.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: put into a particular form of words.

sentence.text: His public pronouncements and statements were brilliantly timed and phrased to send the right signals to Algiers , raise popular expectations at home , and undermine the credibility of the Pflimlin government .

Provisions are , however , phrased differently from lease to lease and the tenant 's adviser will be expected to construe and amend the particular documentation accordingly , but perhaps considering the guidelines I have laid down .

I kept one hand on my sword hilt and the other on my wallet as I mentally phrased the letter I intended to send to Cardinal Wolsey demanding the graveyard be cleared of such a collection of villains .

So suppose we attempt , for example , to phrase accounts of the pragmatic notion of presupposition in terms of appropriateness conditions , we shall find that they wrongly predict conditions of usage .

The good doctor phrases his reply with , ahem , surgical precision .
Their problem is not knowing how to phrase the verdict without inflaming Pakistan .
Charlotte did not phrase her response as a rebuke , but it had much the same effect .

To satisfy the US Senate article 5 was so phrased as to enable each state to respond to aggression only with " such action as it deems necessary , including the use of armed force " .

Some of the most important questions clinicians ask can be phrased in very simple terms :
The question might be phrased as : do you believe it dishonest for a person not to pay a fare which he believes he does not owe ?

The definition of terrorist association , however , was phrased more broadly in the new legislation , and prison terms and fines for terrorist-related offences were increased .

References to the ` incomers " are phrased in terms of the benefits which they might bring .

One tiny privilege , " he sneered , ` when obviously you 're not -- how can I phrase it discreetly ? -- exclusive ? "
In drama there is rarely a single right answer , and it 's often more appropriate to phrase questions so that it is the teacher who does not know , the children who do the clarification :
The way they phrase the question reveals the fact they are thinking in the old materialistic and nationalistic terms .

She tried to think how to phrase the question , then said hesitantly : ` You would tell me , would n't you , if there was something wrong ? "
What the camera did was help you phrase questions .
My hon. Friend is wrong -- if he does not mind my saying so -- in the way in which he phrases his question .
Newman paused as though unsure how to phrase his next words , then burst out : ` Buchanan thinks I murdered Sandy . "
